H0.text: Osmosis is the diffusion of water through a semipermeable membrane down its concentration gradient.

H1.text: Nutrients are the diffusion of water through a semipermeable membrane down its concentration gradient.

H2.text: Mirrors is the diffusion of water through a semipermeable membrane down its concentration gradient.

H3.text: Permable is the diffusion of water through a semipermeable membrane down its concentration gradient.

A4.text: Osmotic transport occurs through viscous flow of the solvent under a pressure gradient.

A5.text: Osmosis is the spontaneous net movement of solvent molecules through a selectively permeable membrane from a region of high water potential (region of lower solute concentration) to a region of low water potential (region of higher solute concentration), in the direction that tends to equalize the solute concentrations on the two sides.

A6.text: When the solutes around a cell become more or less concentrated, osmotic pressure causes water to flow into or out of the cell to equilibrate.

A7.text: In the process of reverse osmosis, water is purified by applying high pressure to a solution and thereby push water through a thin-film composite membrane.

A8.text: Diffusion is the net movement of anything (for example, atoms, ions, molecules, energy) generally from a region of higher concentration to a region of lower concentration.

A9.text: Smaller solutes and fluid pass through the membrane, but the membrane blocks the passage of larger substances.
